::: notes
Cues are elements in the environment that convey important information or trigger an affective reaction.

Our knowledge is quite limited about the link between local variation in climate and breeding phenology of many organisms including frogs.

Rain: leads to reasonably high flows in many river systems – and these cue the initiation of spawning in many fish.
 - Pacific salmon are known to imprint on the chemical signature of their home river
 - Carp are invasive, they dominate many river systems, comprising an average of around 80% of the fish biomass in many areas. Use rain cue to identify critical periods (and hotspots) for removal in Australia 

These are tools we can use...

:::

# Phenology { background-color="#000000"}

 - [Seasonality]{.light-blue} is a measure of distinct within-year conditions or events (e.g., fall, winter, spring)

 - [Predictability]{.orange} is the regularity of recurrence annually

## { background-color="#000000"}

 > ["*Species life histories are finely tuned to capitalize on specialized temporal niches associated with climatic variability*" (Chesson 2000, Chase 2011).]{.white} 

![](../img/rabo_stoic.jpg){fig-align="center"}

::: notes

Altered flow regimes (climate or otherwise) have affected freshwater species that evolved under natural flow patterns by limiting connectivity, reducing flow cues, and eliminating habitat.

Species life histories are finely tuned to capitalize on specialized temporal niches associated with climatic variability (Chesson 2000, Chase 2011). 

“Seasonality is the occurrence of certain obvious biotic and abiotic events or groups of events within a definite limited period or periods of the astronomic (solar, calendar) year.” Essentially, this represents the degree to which within-year conditions are distinct. Lieth (1974:5)

“Predictability is the regularity of recurrence of the within cycle (e.g., annual) distribution of events across multiple cycles”
:::

## Connectivity & Fragmentation {.smaller background-image="../img/fragmentation_glacial_scales.jpg" background-size="contain" background-position="center" background-color="#000000"}

::: notes
So one can imagine in a river network if there are cues to move at certain times that organisms evolved over many eons, shifts in these cues can have dramatic impacts, both direct and indirect.

 - Direct impacts may include shifts in connectivity between breeding and refugia
 - Indirect impacts may include shifts in when food is available, or making food webs less resilient to environmental extremes (i.e., drought, fire)

For RABO, the most direct are the impacts from flow flucutations on egg mass/rearing.

:::
